comments.commentBody: I couldn't agree more with you, Tom.
The Romans eventually hired foreign mercenaries to serve in their legions.  Have we come to that yet?
No doubt there are American generals looking for our Rubicon to cross. This republic is collapsing too.

The parallels to the Roman Empire are gaining truer by the day in the United States. We are now a professional military society, where as the editorial states exceedingly small percentage of families send their fathers, sons, daughters off to war and to serve.
The disparity of wealth is as great.
Military expenditures are consuming far too great a percentage of our yearly budget, now as we see with politicians asking for society to take cuts but to maintain military spending and even increase it.
The class war is now on
Yes the parallels to the Roman Empire are many, they are scary, and we should heed them.
Time to reinstate the draft, everyone serves, no exception, then wars will not be started so easily, or callously.
Not that I abhor your compassion, but the death rate remains one per person, health care insurance or no.

"Lack of insurance is deadly....."

Hasn't that claim been discredited by the Oregon Health Insurance Experiment, which found that Medicaid did not improve enrollees’ health relative to being uninsured?

Hmm, I wonder which side is in the thrall of "ideological obsessions"?
Koch bought Christianity. It has NOTHING to do with the ideas put forth by Christ.

Lack of insurance is deadly for many Americans: 45,000 deaths in 2009 according to a Harvard study. A working age American without insurance has a 40 per cent greater chance of death than an American without insurance.

To two defining characteristics of America today--a 23 per cent child poverty rate and a million schoolchildren homeless (Dept. of Education)--can be added a third, 7.5 million children without health coverage. Texas is the worst with a quarter of its citizens uninsured.

All other advanced democracies have universal public health insurance. To pay for its solitary conceit that health care should be among the most profitable of industries, the U.S. spends more than a trillion dollars more for health care than the average for other OECD countries.

Such is American irrationality on the issue that Obama had to construct a bit of a Rube Goldberg scheme to insure the uninsured. Republicans fancy themselves as advocates of free markets, but they've been horrified by the prospect of a competitive market for health insurance that may drive costs and taxes down. They usually disguise their hatred of social welfare under the guise of debt obsession, but on care for the sick they are exposed in all their callous mendacity.

Republican governors hate the idea of health care for the poor so much they are refusing to allow federally financed expansion of medicaid. They are willing to let tens of thousands die for their ideological obsessions.
What's happened to the U.S.?

That's nuts!! People without insurance can't go to the doctor, it's not a shortage of doctors, and yes, when all, many more any way, are insured we will need more doctors, nurses and all the rest, and provisions for such, grants for school and all are built into Obamacare.

Good points.

What doesn't come up in any of the discussion//ranting about Obamacare is the fact that the process to become an MD in the US is designed to limit competition. By limiting competition, creating shortage in the MD supply, the AMA keeps compensation up for its members.

The AMA will say it is to ensure competence and patient safety. However, no controlled studies have been done to my knowledge that compare the quality of US docs with 12 years of gruesome training against the quality of docs who have had something different.

Already we are seeing a greater use of nurse practitioners to alleviate the need for when the expertise of a physician may not be required.
Many of them are brilliant and provide excellent care while under the wing of a physician.

Many people were not getting medical care. We say they lacked insurance, but what they lacked was doctors.

Our medical system is sized for the number of people to whom it provides care. For those it does not now care, it has not extra doctors, nurses, clinic hours, or hospital beds.

One predictable resulting complication will be shortage. Shortage is inconvenient, and it drives up prices. Shortage also leads to cutting corners, and keeping lesser quality in use.

Now it is a good thing that millions of us will have care. We ought to provide that many doctors, etc. But the fact is we don't. That is the real, underlying problem, that so many go without care.

That will take time to adjust. It will cause complaints. Those complaints will be reasonable. But they will be because we are doing the right thing, rather than continuing to do the wrong thing.

I had my baby girl about 3/4 of my way through my doctoral study. The university where I was did not have a maternity leave policy for graduate students, but I was allowed to take 10 weeks off without a stipend (basically I had to be signed up as on-leave for medical reasons for a quarter). I am grateful I could take that time to bond with my baby. But since a lot of female doctoral students are in their mid 20s and beyond, I think universities could really be more encouraging and supportive

According to data given by the Pew Research Center (http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/files/2010/10/college-enrollment.pdf appendix A1), total enrollment in community college has increased from 2.23 million in 1982 to 2.71 million in 2006.

What is presented as a crisis in the Century Foundation report is actually fantastic news: more poor students are attending college than were before. The top quartile is less represented in community college compared to 1982, but this should be accounted for by increased enrollment in 4-year colleges. All quartiles are more educated than they were in 1982.
I live next to Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn. The constant roar of vehicular traffic is the real insult to my senses. The smell of car exhaust at rush hour is an insult to my senses.

But I'm not complaining about your avatar! Why would I? It's your avatar. I was just posting an avatar-related factoid, otherwise known as a clue that confuses way more than it illuminates.

We are doing much more than just replacing old parts, or modernizing our nukes, or updating them.

We are building a whole new class of super expensive super capable smart weapons. We are putting into these every single thing from every single wish list. This is an extreme of gold plating. It is solid gold.

There are some things that must be done to very old bombs to keep them reliable. We are doing vastly more than that. It is sold as this necessity, but the huge money is going into things that are not at all that necessity.

Thirty and forty year old plastics, and short half life items that have degraded for decades, all need to be fixed. We are doing that, and must. But that is not where all this money is going.

When I was much younger and definitely more attractive, I travelled alone to Denmark, Sweden and Norway.

While I had one difficult encounter with a very unpleasant man, everyone on the bus was immediately aware that he was trying to talk to me. The bus driver even called me to the front and told me where to get off - and the man did not. I have never forgotten that experience and how I was taken care of by strangers.

Since most people in Scandinavia speak many languages including English, that makes traveling quite easy. And in the summer the sun sets very late (if at all) so it is light well into the night. It is expensive but there are ways to keep it inexpensive.

Good luck.

The problem is and always will be confirmation bias and motivated ignorance.

Those who have already decided that Obamacare is an attempt by government to take away their medical care and give it to someone less deserving will find anecdotal evidence to support their beliefs. They will never listen to statistical research. They will not even accept the evidence of their own eyes or pocketbooks.

All the same, stand by for the results to be even better than you imagine. Not because it was a good plan, it probably was not. But is was most certainly better than nothing. More to the point it was a change and a chance for all those who wished to make it work to do so.

Those who believe that insurance companies are all evil businesses will have the chance to learn that they are made up of human beings, people who are mostly good and when given the chance to help their fellows they will. The ACA gives them the cover they need to tell the stockholders and their super cargoes the accountants that the law of the land is forcing them to do what they really wanted to do all along.

I have seen this same thing with both OSHA and the EPA for the last 40 years. The law gave workers and middle managers the ability to take the companies they worked for in the direction they desired to go.

I am saying we may still lose in 2014. Obama hatred is a strong emotion and midterms are hard on the president's party. But if Obama can tough it out we can probably end this in our favor in 2016.

It seems to me they provide a ready-made constituency for the Republicans, that, like many, if not most such constituencies trades political contributions and media campaigns in exchange for legislative action (or inaction)  that keeps its profitable little world humming along at the expense of the consumer.

@Rohit: "at least you wars safe - from cars - on the sidewalk. Not so with bikes."

Tell that to the couple dozen or so pedestrians killed ON THE SIDEWALK by NYC drivers every year. Contrast that with the zero pedestrians killed on the sidewalk since... ever? (Perhaps you might be able to find one case if you look back far enough.)

Let's hope that Obamacare brings some sanity and choice to the individual insurance market.  My premiums abruptly rose by 26% this past year (I didn't get sick or have any accidents, nor did my benefits change).  Neither my insurer nor our state insurance commissioner provided any explanation for the sudden jump.  Changing insurance companies requires you to go through a gauntlet of multi-page health questionnaires.  Even without being sick, insurers can still decline to cover you, even if you're just looking for high-deductible, catastrophic coverage.  If our legislators ever had to spend 5 minutes looking for coverage on the individual insurance market, we'd have had health insurance reform decades ago.

Jimbo, Great comment. The military has its own problem with benefits under the current Tea Party GOP. But it is good to know that there are moderate sensible Republicans willing to step up and speak out what is right.

A client of mine, headed by a retired Marine Major said that he didn't want the general public to have insurance like his because they were not worth it. He is an African American Democrat too. Just goes to show that these problems are really complicated and that fear is an enormous problem.

Who wouldn't  love Tricare? The problem with it is the same as the problem with Medicare. It's too cheap. Who do you think is picking up the real cost of Tricare or do you really think that your premium actually covers the costs of a highly efficient program. The reality is that Tricare is bankrupting the military budget and cries out for reform. The Joint Chiefs know this only too well. Unfortunately, the future of Tricare  as presently funded does not work.

I had emergency hospital care, a baby and back surgery under Tricare and I LOVED IT. We are now in the private sector, and it is a freekin' nightmare.

I have told anyone and everyone how great "socialized medicine" is, and few have listened, to my sorrow.

My wife and I have single payer healthcare here in the States, and we love it. It cost $110/ month each, and after that, the only costs are for prescription meds, and the costs are negligible. No co-pays, no deductables, no caps, no pre-existing condition barriers. We select our doctors, which means suberb doctors in enlightened Seattle.

Are you interested? It is widely available, but you have to enter the system before you are around 30. It also provides a generous COLA protected pension, which starts when you retire, even at age 38.

Too good to be true? We are covered by Medicare and Tricare. Tricare is enabled by serving a minimum of 20 years of Military service. It has no connection with the VA. I retired as an Air Force colonel 33 years ago as a colonel, though Tricare benefits are identical for all ranks and grades. My wife and I both take Nexium. Cost for a 90 days supply? $3, and that includes the cost of mailing it to us. Unlike Medicare, Tricare can bargain for drug costs.

We have seen the future and it works. We believe that healthcare is a basic human right, and that our government is the ultimate employer when all else fails.

Am I a socialist? Not really, but I wouldn't dread it. I am an Eisenhower Republican, who will likely never vote for another Republican.

Today's Republicans hate Obamacare because they fear it will be a huge success. Dr. Krugman once again hits the nail on the head.

The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.

There were similar shortages in medical caregivers when medicare came into being, but they were relatively short-lived, and few want to return to the days prior.  The number of illegal immigrants that may now get insurance is tiny compared to the number of citizens who can't obtain insurance either because of a medical condition or it's too expensive (or both).  So, I'm not sure you can blame illegal immigrants (many of whom consider America their home and are productive and integrated members of our society) for the shortage of care that can be brought about by millions of Americans finally getting coverage that they need.

I believe there is a great potential in Obamacare to lower the costs in the future. These future cost cutting mechanisms will be based on 2 major elements:

1. Preventive medicine
2. National Electronic Health Records.

This second feature will be a gold mine to research for cheaper and more effective outcomes and in future personalized medicine.

Here's what I don't understand about all the comments hating on Google Glass (which for the record I will never own, I'd rather have another DSLR)... unless you live in the middle of nowhere you are now being recorded many times in the day (if not continuously). If you step into a public hospital you are being recorded continuously. If you go to a bank, a large school, public spaces in almost any university, any government building (including the outside), most major streets of any large city, almost every small retailer and every larger one or if you work for a Fortune 500 company, you are being photographed hundreds if not thousands of times a day. In some instances your are being video recorded as well.

If you have a cell phone in your pocket (even a plain phone) then your carrier knows where you sleep, where you work, where you like to eat out, who your friends are, whether you own a pet, what music you like to listen to, what some of your interests are and they sell that information to others, so the corporate world already knows all about you.

In the end that's thing, in public places, you never had any privacy to begin with. It's not in the Constitution and the Supreme Court has only grudgingly allowed a very limited, narrow reading of "public privacy". I'm not saying this is great and how it should be, but it's what is and it has been for decades, so it's really late to cry wolf now. Incidentally, it would require amending the Constitution to stop it.

First of all, this is nothing like the dilemma of the Yooks and the Zooks. How someone eats their bread is of no concern to me, as it has no effect whatsoever on me. However, taking may picture most certainly does.

Second, it's not so much the act of taking my picture that's a problem. It's what happens WITH the photo or video afterwards. Does it end up on Facebook, a blog, Instagram, Twitter, or the taker's Flickr or Smugmug account? If someone is taking a traditional photo or video, it's easy for me to ask them not to include me or to move out of the frame. It's not so easy when the photo or video is being taken without my knowledge, even if deception is not intended.

Austerian theory has been repeatedly infirmed by these events.

You don't have to take pity on me...I have no axe to grind. I was making an observation that "all men," as in all people, share the same fate; we all go to the grave. In that light, I think commerce does take a back seat to motherhood. I think mothers' don't lose their focus on business so much as they are forced to choose. If Mr. Tudor Jones' didn't want to lose a bright, motivated female worker, he was in a position to make accommodations. But it doesn't seem to me that he and others in the business world want to be bothered. It's a fact that women in the professional workforce have difficulty holding on to their positions once they have babies. In the business world, no one wants to be your friend if you don't play like the boys. It is not by chance that women represent a minority of those in the top echelons of the professional world.

And contrary to your assumptions, I've been blessed with a very good father, husband, and several male bosses who were more than wonderful to me. But I do think that it's still a man's world. I graduated from Columbia University and got my law degree from Georgetown. But the law firm in which I worked did not even have a maternity leave policy before I asked. When I was interviewing for jobs, a lawyer at one firm I interviewed with was pregnant. I asked if she thought this was a family friendly firm. She answered that she felt she had put in her time and earned her right to be pregnant. That reply should give anyone pause...

Remember, those who have insurance are already paying for the uninsured's medical services because the doctors and hospitals must in turn charge more for the uninsured that show up at the emergency room.  Some of those currently uninsured may also prefer to buy their own medical insurance if they don't have to pay an arm and a leg for it.

"shortage of doctors"?

Have you no faith in free markets? Where there is demand, supply is sure to follow.

A common complaint from those who oppose Obama Care is that there is a shortage of doctors which will be made worse by extending health care access to more (undeserving) people.

Even the famous fake couple Harry & Louise, who helped defeat Clinton era health care reform, have disavowed this callous "I got mine" argument, realizing that they could be one layoff and/or pre-existing condition away from "I got nothing" under the previous system.

But the fact is that there is a huge amount of waste in the allocation of resources today. Every older senior I talk to describes doctors pushing treatments on them that they don't want. The Dartmouth Health Atlas estimates waste at 30% of total health care cost is waste.

Obama Care tackles this problem on many fronts, from competition to better data and transparency to accountable care incentives. It will take years but we will move forward instead of back.

It's a horribly disastrous start! It would have been better if it has failed! It's an almost complete capitulation to the insurance companies, which is exactly what we need to do away with. But this is the land of unfettered (corrupt) capitalism, so that's not likely to happen anytime in the foreseeable future, is it?

In the meantime, as a self-employed Californian, I pay nearly $1,000 (yes, that's one thousand dollars!) *per month* for my health care insurance, and I still have to pay plenty of significant co-pays, etc! I absolutely expect that the astronomical rates I pay will only continue to increase, well beyond the general inflation rate, Obamacare or no.

Don't forget that within a day of the law passing, 10 Democrats had received death threats, the noose fax to James Clyburn, the sniper threats, the cut propane line at a democrat's brother's house (after the wrong address was posted on a TeaParty website as the of the Democrat congressman), the brick throwing/office vandalism of Reps. Louise Slaughter and Gabrielle Giffords.

Don't forget the spitting, homphobic, racist slurs at Democrat Reps entering the capital, Sarah Palin's facebook page targeting Democrats with "just surveyor's marks" or the effect of the lies that Obamacare is death panels. Don't forget the endless GOP obstruction, delays, and amendments like Coburn's prohibiting Viagra for child molesters, or the Stupak executive order.

Don't forget the bill was passed by reconciliation, and instead of risking the guarantee of healthcare for all, by sending it back to the House again, Bernie Sanders got Harry Reed to promise to bring up a future bill of either Medicare for all or a public option?

Don't forget implementation will be as tough (see Reagan's campaign ad against Medicare), but eventually as popular as Social Security. It's a start.
